Literature Review: The field of metabolic engineering has made significant strides in the production of industrially relevant compounds through the assembly of heterologous pathways in microbial hosts. However, the optimization of these pathways for high product yield remains a challenge, primarily due to issues such as low pathway flux and the off-target consumption of intermediates. These challenges are further complicated by the need to maintain cellular health, especially in the presence of toxic intermediates. Nature has evolved sophisticated spatial organization strategies to enhance metabolic pathway efficiency, which has inspired bioengineers to develop analogous strategies in synthetic systems. This literature review explores the theoretical and practical aspects of multienzyme organization and encapsulation, focusing on protein scaffolding and encapsulation within proteinaceous shells, as innovative approaches to overcome bottlenecks in metabolic engineering. Protein scaffolding involves the spatial organization of enzymes within a cell to enhance pathway efficiency by minimizing the diffusion of intermediates and increasing local concentrations of substrates. This strategy has been successfully applied in various metabolic engineering efforts, leading to significant improvements in product yield. For example, Dueber et al. (2009) demonstrated the use of synthetic protein scaffolds to increase the production of mevalonate in Escherichia coli by colocalizing three enzymes involved in the mevalonate biosynthesis pathway. Similarly, Conrado et al. (2012) utilized protein scaffolds to enhance the production of glucaric acid, showcasing the versatility of this approach in optimizing metabolic pathways. Encapsulation of enzymes within proteinaceous shells, such as bacterial microcompartments (BMCs), represents another promising strategy for enhancing metabolic pathway efficiency. BMCs are self-assembling protein structures that encapsulate enzymes and their substrates, thereby creating a specialized microenvironment that can increase pathway flux and protect the cell from toxic intermediates. The potential of BMCs in metabolic engineering has been explored in several studies. For instance, Lawrence et al. (2014) engineered BMCs to encapsulate a synthetic pathway for the production of 1,2-propanediol, demonstrating the feasibility of using BMCs for the compartmentalization of heterologous pathways. Similarly, Kerfeld et al. (2018) highlighted the modularity of BMCs and their potential for the design of custom metabolic compartments. The integration of protein scaffolding and encapsulation strategies offers a powerful toolkit for metabolic engineers to overcome the limitations of traditional pathway optimization approaches. By mimicking nature's spatial organization strategies, these approaches enable the precise control of enzyme localization and substrate channeling, leading to enhanced pathway efficiency and product yield. However, the implementation of these strategies also presents challenges, including the need for precise control over scaffold and shell assembly, as well as the potential impact on cellular physiology. Future research in this area will likely focus on the development of more sophisticated scaffolds and shells, as well as the integration of these strategies with other metabolic engineering tools, such as genome editing and computational modeling, to further enhance pathway optimization. In conclusion, the theoretical and practical aspects of multienzyme organization and encapsulation represent a promising frontier in metabolic engineering. By leveraging the principles of spatial organization, bioengineers can overcome the bottlenecks associated with heterologous pathway assembly, paving the way for the sustainable production of a wide range of industrially relevant compounds.
